I will give you a Coq proof state, including both hypotheses and a specific goal and your need to prove it. Your response should be a singular code block of Coq proof, without any additional explanation or commentary. Follow to these guidelines:
Introduce variables using unique names to avoid any conflicts.
Keep each command distinct and separated, avoid concatenations like ';' or '[cmd|cmd]'.
Organize your proof with bullets like '-', '+', and '*' instead of braces ({, }). Shift to their double symbols like '--' and '++', when necessary.
Effectively use given premises, follow the syntax and structure demonstrated in the examples provided.

Example 1:

Hypotheses:
n, m: nat
IHn: m + n = n + m

Goal:
m + S n = S n + m

Proof:
```simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Example 2:
Hypotheses:

Goal:
forall n m : nat, m + n = n + m

```intros n m. induction n.
- simpl. auto.
- simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

sss_step = fun (P : code) (st1 st2 : state) => exists (k : nat) (l : list instr) (i : instr) (r : list instr) (d : data), P = (k, l ++ i :: r) /\ st1 = (k + length l, d) /\ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 : code -> state -> state -> Prop
subcode_sss_compute_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st3 : state), P <sc Q -> out_code (fst st3) P -> Q // st1 -> > st3 -> exists st2 : state, P // st1 -> > st2 /\ Q // st2 -> > st3 /\ out_code (fst st2) P
subcode_sss_compute_trans : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 -> > st2 -> Q // st2 -> > st3 -> Q // st1 -> > st3
Inductive sss_steps (P : code) : nat -> state -> state -> Prop := in_sss_steps_0 : forall st : state, P//st-[0] -> st | in_sss_steps_S : forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n] -> st3 -> P//st1-[S n] -> st3 Arguments sss_steps _ _%nat_scope Arguments in_sss_steps_S [P] [n]%nat_scope [st1 st2 st3]
subcode_sss_progress_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (p : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), out_code (fst st3) P -> P <sc Q -> P // st1 -+> st2 -> Q//st1-[p] -> st3 -> exists q : nat, q < p /\ Q//st2-[q] -> st3
subcode_sss_progress : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 -+> st2 -> Q // st1 -+> st2
sss_stall = fun (ii : instr) (st : state) => forall st' : state, ~ st ⟬ ii ⦒ st' : instr -> state -> Prop
subcode_sss_terminates_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st st1 : state), Q // st ↓ -> P <sc Q -> P // st ~~> st1 -> Q // st1 ↓

``` 
intros.
apply HQ1.
intros.
apply sss_terminates_ind with (st := st1).
+ intros. apply out_code. 
+ intros. intros. apply H0 with (st2 := st2).
++ apply subcode_sss_compute_trans with (st2 := st2).
  - assumption.
  - apply H1.
++ apply subcode_sss_terminates_inv with (Q := P0); assumption.
```

original: intros. apply HQ1. intros. apply sss_terminates_ind with (st := st1). + intros. apply out_code. + intros. intros. apply H0 with (st2 := st2). ++ apply subcode_sss_compute_trans with (st2 := st2). - auto. - apply H1. ++ apply subcode_sss_terminates_inv with (Q := P0); auto.
